hypotheses.prediction: IF primary rat cortical neurons are exposed to ketamine at 5-10 µM for 1-2 hours, THEN JC-1 fluorescence ratio (red/green) will show a transient depolarization of 15-30% at 30-60 min followed by partial recovery, compared to vehicle. At 50-100 µM (supra-anesthetic equivalent), ΔΨm depolarization will exceed 40% without recovery by 4 hours.
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: Culture DIV14 rat cortical neurons in 96-well plates. Treat with ketamine (1, 5, 10, 25, 50, 100 µM) ± VDAC1 inhibitor DIDS (100 µM). Measure ΔΨm via JC-1 live imaging at 15, 30, 60, 120, 240 min using plate reader and confocal. Parallel wells for TMRM confirmation and MTT viability at 4h and 24h.
hypotheses.null_outcome: No significant ΔΨm change at any dose within 4h, or identical magnitude/kinetics across all doses (no dose-pathway isomorphism).

hypotheses.prediction: IF mice receive ketamine (10 mg/kg IP, sub-anesthetic) preceded by the mitochondrial uncoupler FCCP (low-dose ICV, 0.5 nmol) or VDAC1 inhibitor DIDS (ICV, 10 nmol), THEN the antidepressant-like effect in the forced swim test at 2h post-injection will be abolished (immobility time returns to ≥90% of vehicle control), even though BDNF protein levels in PFC remain elevated.
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: Male C57BL/6 mice (n=12/group, 6 groups) with pre-implanted ICV cannulae. Groups: (1) vehicle+vehicle, (2) vehicle+ketamine, (3) FCCP+ketamine, (4) DIDS+ketamine, (5) FCCP+vehicle, (6) DIDS+vehicle. ICV pretreatment 30 min before ketamine IP. FST and sucrose preference at 2h and 24h. Sacrifice at 2.5h; PFC dissected for BDNF ELISA, ATP assay, and JC-1 staining of acute slices.
hypotheses.expected_outcome: Ketamine alone reduces immobility ~45% and increases PFC ATP/BDNF. FCCP or DIDS pretreatment blocks behavioral improvement and ATP increase but BDNF remains partially elevated, demonstrating that mitochondrial function is required downstream of or parallel to BDNF for behavioral output.
hypotheses.null_outcome: FCCP/DIDS pretreatment has no effect on ketamine's behavioral response, indicating mitochondrial bioenergetics are dispensable for rapid antidepressant action.
controls: each blocker alone (to exclude depressogenic effects of mitochondrial disruption)
rapamycin+ketamine group (mTOR blockade positive control for behavioral abolition)

hypotheses.prediction: IF isolated mouse brain mitochondria or cultured cortical neurons are treated with (2R,6R)-HNK at 1-10 µM, THEN oxygen consumption rate (OCR) for basal and maximal respiration will increase by 15-40% within 60 min, and this effect will persist in the presence of AP5 (NMDAR antagonist, 50 µM) but will be abolished by NBQX (AMPAR antagonist, 10 µM, in neurons only) or by complex I inhibitor rotenone (0.5 µM).
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: Seahorse XFe96: (A) Isolated mouse brain mitochondria treated with HNK (0.5, 1, 5, 10, 20 µM) ± rotenone (0.5 µM), measuring OCR with MitoStress test (oligomycin/FCCP/antimycin A). (B) DIV14 cortical neurons treated with HNK (same
hypotheses.expected_outcome: HNK at 5-10 µM increases basal OCR ~25% and maximal OCR ~20% in both isolated mitochondria and neurons. In isolated mitochondria (no receptors), the effect persists with AP5/NBQX, confirming a direct mitochondrial target. In neurons, NBQX partially attenuates (~50%) suggesting dual mechanism. Rotenone abolishes the OCR increase, localizing the target to complex I or upstream.
hypotheses.null_outcome: HNK produces no OCR change in isolated mitochondria at any concentration, and all neuronal effects are fully blocked by NBQX, indicating purely AMPAR-mediated mechanism with no direct mitochondrial component.
readouts: complex I specific activity (nmol NADH oxidized/min/mg)
ATP production rate (Seahorse real-time ATP assay)

hypotheses.prediction: IF the dose-response curves for ketamine's synaptogenic effect (spine density increase in PFC layer V pyramidal neurons) and neurotoxic effect (caspase-3 activation or LDH release) are fitted to Hill equations, THEN the synaptogenic target will show a Hill coefficient of 1.0-1.5 (hyperbolic, low cooperativity) with EC₅₀ ~5 µM, while the neurotoxic target will show a Hill coefficient of 2.5-4.0 (sigmoidal, high cooperativity) with EC₅₀ ~50-80 µM, creating a ≥5-fold therapeutic window where synaptogenesis saturates before neurotoxicity engages.
